availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.
The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0).
Permission to reproduce the graphic images in this archive has been granted by the owners of the originals for this publication only.

notesStmt.note:
As Floyd Stovall has noted, the few datable references in this notebook (e.g., the fighting at Sebastopol during the Crimean War) are to events from about 1853 to late 1854, shortly before the first publication of Leaves of Grass. See Floyd Stovall, "Dating Whitman's Early Notebooks," Studies in Bibliography 24 (1971), 197–204. See also Edward Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:138–155.
This notebook contains much draft material for Whitman's early poems, although this fact has not often been recognized by scholars. Both Stovall and Grier point out that most of the connections to printed works are to poems and prose published in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass but that the notebook also contains material clearly related to things that were first printed in the second (1856) and third (1860–1861) editions.
Whitman revised the text on leaf 23 verso to include a rather long passage that exceeded the space available between existing lines of text and therefore overflowed onto the facing page (leaf 24 recto).

A prince in Polish Austria near Hungary on his estate on the highway, puts up a perpetual inn where all wayfarers are entertained free of charge; this he keeps always open, and gives meat and bread and lodgings—and sometimes comes to amuse himself with the guests.

work.p: This paragraph is possibly related to a three-line passage on the same theme in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "Song of Myself." The second of those lines reads, "And I say it as as great to be a woman as to be a man."

div2.p: I have been asked, Which is the greater, the man or the woman?—Yes, I tell you, with the same answer that I tell whether Time is greater than space—and wh

work.p: This paragraph seems likely to have informed the passage in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "Song of Myself," in which the speaking persona says, "I do not snivel [. . .] That life is a suck and a sell [. . .] ."

div2.p: The life of man on earth is the chef d'ouvre of all things.— What then! is it a suck?—Has God tried conceived a joke, and tried it on, and is it a small one?

work.p: These draft lines were incorporated, in revised form, into the seventh poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was eventually titled "Song of the Answerer."

lg.head: Of the poet
lg.l:
He walks with perfect
ease among a congress
of kings,

And one king saithsays
to another, Here is
our equal, a prince whom
we knew not before

Then the great authors
take him for an author

And the great soldiers
for a captain

The sailors know
that he has followed
the sea,

The English believe that
comes of Saxon stock
And the Italians f

work.p: This line contributed to the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was eventually titled "Song of Myself."

work.p: The imagery and phrasing of these lines bears some resemblance to a passage in the fourth "Chants Democratic" poem of the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "Our Old Feuillage," in which Whitman writes of "White drift spooning ahead [. . .] ."

The bluey spoon-drift, like
a white race-horse of
brine, speeds before me

work.p: A later version of this passage was incorporated into the poem eventually titled "A Song for Occupations," when Whitman revised it for publication in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass.

div2.p: Of writers there are plenty who pay all demands upon them, if folks are willing to take notes, or paper acceptances of any sort; but only one out centuries who gives ready solid cash.–

It is a terrible sign of the human soul that it will not own any limit, even the widest.—The moment we knew the diameter of the earth to be eight thousand miles, it became no great thing to us.—With all the appalling grandeur of astronomy, if we could fix the line beyond which there was no more material universe, our soul, I think, would pine away and begin its death sickness

work.p: Floyd Stovall has posited a connection between this passage and the 1856 poem "Poem of the Sayers of the Words of the Earth" (later titled "A Song of the Rolling Earth"), an argument that is strengthened by Whitman's "overleaf" notation, which ties it to the passage on the following page. There, the phrasing more clearly echoes the printed poem.

div2.p:
☞ over leaf
The Nature is an ethereal mirror deep deep and floating
The mirror that Nature holds and hides behind is deep and floating and ethereal and faithful.
—in it a man always sends and sees himself in it— from
it himself he reflects
his the fashion of his
gods and all his religions and politics and books and art and social and public institutions—ignorance or knowledge—kindness or cruelty—grossness or refinement—definitions or chaos—each is unerringly sent back to him or her who curiously gazes.

work.p: The phrase "face of the mother of many children" appears twice in the sixth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. That poem was eventually titled "Faces."

Edward Grier, in Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), has posited a connection between this passage and the following lines in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric": "The female contains all qualities and tempers them . . . . she is in her place . . . . she moves with perfect balance, / She is all things duly veiled . . . . she is both passive and active . . . . she is to conceive daughters as well as sons and sons as well as daughters." See Grier, 1:141.

Floyd Stovall has noted the connection between this passage and lines in the 1856 poem "Poem of the Sayers of the Words of the Earth" (later titled "A Song of the Rolling Earth"), in which the Earth is personified as a "beautiful sister" who holds "in her hand what has the character of a mirror." See Stovall, "Dating Whitman's Early Notebooks," Studies in Bibliography 24 (1971), 202.

div2.p: There is a fullsized woman of calm and voluptuous beauty. . . . the unspeak unspeakable charm of the face of the mother of many children is the charm of her face . . . . she is clean and sweet and simple with immortal health . . . she holds always before her what has the quality of a mirror, and dwells serenely behind it.—

When out of a feast I eat bread only corn and roast potatoes fo for my dinner, through my own voluntary choice it is very well and I much content, but if some arrogant head of the table prevent me by force from touching any thing but corn and potatoes then is my anger roused.—
Every one that speaks his word for slavery is himself the worst slave—the spirit of a freeman is not light enough in him to show that all the fatness of the earth were bitter to a bondaged neck.—

work.p: This paragraph probably developed into the following lines of "Poem of the Road" in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass, (eventually titled "Song of the Open Road"): "The efflux of the soul is happiness—here is happiness, / I think it pervades the air, waiting at all times, / Now it flows into us—we are rightly charged."

div2.p: In the respect of happiness or extasyecstasy, the beautiful gas is pervades the air continually, and we only need to be rightly tuned and conditioned, in order that it may catch to us ? ?(like gunpowder catches to fire) and pass flow into us like one river into another.

work.p: The image in this passage is probably the basis for the following line in the 1856 poem that was eventually titled "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry": "On the river the shadowy group, the big steam-tug closely flanked on each side by the barges—the hay-boat, the belated lighter [. . .]".

work.p: This passage is possibly related to the following couplet of the opening poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, later titled "Song of Myself": "Logic and sermons never convince, / The damp of the night drives deeper into my soul."

div2.p: The test of the goodness or truth of any thing is the soul itself—whatever does good to the soul, soothes, refreshes, cheers, inspirits, consoles, &c.—that is so, easy enough—But doctrines, sermons, logic ? ?

work.p: The first two lines of this draft are probably related to this line in the second poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was eventually titled "A Song for Occupations": "If you meet some stranger in the street and love him or her, do I not often meet strangers in the street and love them?"

Edward Grier has speculated that these lines are related to a stanza in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric." That passage begins, "I have perceived that to be with those I like is enough" and goes on to say that "I do not ask any more delight" than "To pass among them . . to touch any one . . . . to rest my arm ever so lightly round his or her neck for a moment." See Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:144.

Edward Grier sees these lines as connected to a section of the poem first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and eventually titled "Song of the Open Road." Although it doesn't use any of the same phrasing, the passage in the published poem expresses a similar idea, especially in these lines: "Why are there men and women that while they are nigh me the sun-light expands my blood? / [. . .] What is it I interchange so suddenly with strangers?" See Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:144.

Edward Grier has noted a possible connection between these lines and the poem first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and eventually titled "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry." See Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:144.

Do you it is to

Do you know what it is to

to have men and women
crave the touch of

work.p: As Edward Grier has pointed out, the idea in this passage "is central in the 1855 Preface [. . .]." See Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:144.

div2.ab: Th not— —must be the poets I would have The poets I would have must be a power in the state, and an engrossing power in the state.

work.p: Edward Grier has noted the possible relationship between these lines and the 1855 Preface, where Whitman mentions "drivers of horses" in a series of images that evince "a residence of the poetic in outdoor people." See Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:144.

Edward Grier has noted that the phrase "drivers of horses," which appears twice in these lines, indicates a possible connection between these lines and the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was later titled "Song of Myself." In that poem, "drivers of horses" are named as one of various sorts of manual laborers about whom the narrator says, "I can eat and sleep with them week in and week out." See Grier, Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts (New York: New York University Press, 1984), 1:144.

div2.head: Criticism
div2.p: He leaps over or dives under for the time, all the reforms and propositions that worry these days and goes to the making of powerful men and women.—These With these he says, all reforms, all good, will come.—Without these all reforms all good, all outside effects, are useless and helpless.—

work.p: Whitman used the lines beginning "If the general" and "If you are happy" in the untitled third poem of the "Debris" cluster in the 1860 edition of Leaves of Grass. This poem, with the last line omitted, was retitled "Leaflets" in the 1867 edition, after which it was dropped altogether.

lg.l:
No one can realize anything
unless he has it in him . . . .
or has been it

It must certainly tally with what is
in him . . . . otherwise it is
all blank to him.

The annals the past, light, space
—if I have them not in
me, I have them not at all

The future is in me as a seed
or nascent thought.

If the general has not the
best a good
army in himself
he has no a good army . . . . otherwise he has a poor no army worth mentioning.

If you poor— are rich in

located . . . .
if not whate

of yourself you can
be are happy . . . . for but I tell
you cannot be happy
through by others any more
than you can beget
a child through by others
. . . . or conceive a child
through by others.
I write not the hymns

I see th the building of churches to
God . . . .

If I build a church it
shall be the a church
of to men and women

If I write hymns they
shall be all to men
and women,

If I become a devotee
it shall be to men
and women.

div2.p: It is not a labor of clothing or putting on or describing—it is a labor of clearing away and not reducing—for every thing is beautiful in itself and perfect—and the office of the poet is to remove what stands in the way of our perceiving the beauty and perfection

div2.head: My final aim
div2.p: To concentrate around me the leaders of all reforms—transcendentalist spiritualists, free soilers

work.p: These lines contributed to the passage beginning "A slave at auction!" in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. This poem was eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

work.p: These lines contributed to the passage beginning "A woman at auction," in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. This poem was eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

div2.head: American opera
div2.ab: when a song is sung the accompaniment to be by only one instrument or two instruments the rest silent.
—the vocal performer to make far more of his song, or solo part, by by-play, attitudes, expressions, movements, &c. than is usual at all in the made by the Italian opera singers—
—The American opera to be far more simple, and give far more scope to the persons enacting the characters

work.p: These lines probably contributed to the poem eventually titled "A Song of the Rolling Earth," which was first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass.

Have you in you the enthusiasm for the battles of Re Bunker Hill and Long Island and Washington's retreat?—Have you the heroic feeling for—— —Look forth then fo— there is still occasion for courage and devotion—Nature is not so poor but there is always occasion for courage and determined power and defiance

work.p: This jotting is probably related to the line in the 1856 "Poem of Salutation" (eventually titled "Salut au Monde!") that reads, "I myself make the only growth by which I can be appreciated."

work.p: These lines contributed to the description, in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, of the "Bridegroom-night of love." This poem was eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

lg.head: Bridalnight.

work.p: These notes contributed to the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

work.p: These lines are probably related to the following passage in the Preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass: "Here comes one among the wellbeloved stonecutters and plans with decision and science and sees the solid and beautiful forms of the future where there are now no solid forms."

These lines are perhaps related to a passage in the 1856 poem "Poem of The Sayers of The Words of The Earth," which exhorts the "sayers of the earth" to "Work on, age after age" for "When the materials are all prepared, the architects shall appear." This poem was eventually titled "A Song of the Rolling Earth."

among the stonecutters
and the heaps of
cut stone

poem describes how the

an indescribable faith,
go on age after age in
their work—and at last
came architects and
used each in its place
the stones they
had cut

work.p: This note is probably connected to the development of the 1856 "Poem of the Road," which was eventually titled "Song of the Open Road."

work.p: Images from these notes were used in several widely separated lines of the second poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was eventually titled "A Song for Occupations."

work.p: Whitman used a version of this line in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was later titled "Song of Myself."

div2.l: The bugle calls in the ballroom—the dancers gentlemen lead out go for their partners—the playing begins—the dancers bow to each other.

work.p: The note here about the "swimming—bath" is possibly connected to the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "I Sing the Body Electric," where the phrase "The swimmer naked in the swimming bath" appears.

work.p: The description here of dishes on a table probably contributed to the image, in the second poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, of "the dishes of breakfast, dinner, supper." The poem was eventually titled "A Song for Occupations."

div2.ab: The dishes on the daily table—the coffee the roast meat—the oysters—the coffee and cornbread and rye and wheatbread,

work.p: These lines are perhaps related to the penultimate paragraph of the Preface to the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in which Whitman claims that literature and other cultural institutions and practices will inevitably be judged according to "American standards." In making such determinations, one must ask questions such as "Are its disposals without ignominious distinctions?"

lg.l: The questions are such as these

Has his life shown the true
American character?

And does it show the true American
character?

Has he been easy and friendly with
his workmen?—Has he been
the stern master of slaves?

Has he been for making ignominious
distinctions?—Has he
respected the literary classes and
looked on the ignorant classes with

If there be animal some brute that is very
sagacious and intelligent

And a being of our human race
no more sagacious and intelligent
than that animal—is one
preferred to the other?

div2.p: Equality of all rights and persons is imperiously demanded by selfpreservation.—The cause of the ruin of all states that have been ruined has been that the whole body of the inhabitants without exception were not equally interested in the preservation of those states or cities—or that a portion was degraded

work.p: The notes here regarding male beauty contributed to the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was ultimately titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

div2.ab: The expression of a wellperfectmade man appears not only in his face—but in his limbs—The motion of his hands and arms and all his joints—his walk—the carriage of his neck—and the flex of his waist and hips

Dress does not hide him. The
quality he has and the clean strong sweet supple nature he has strike through his the cotton and woolen.—To see him walk is a spectacle or aconveys the impression of to hearing a beautiful poem.ૼTo see his back and the back of his neck and shoulderside is a spectacle. Great in the body!—There is something in the close presence touch of any candid and cleanhuman being person . . . .—what it is I do not know . . . . but it fills me with wonderful and exquisite sensations.—It is enough to be with him or— with her.—
describe the perfect male body—pancratist—perfect in all gynasia

work.p: This note is possibly related to a three-line description in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass of "The wrestle of wrestlers." This poem was later titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

div2.ab: Poem of the Wrestlers

work.p: This line was used in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was eventually titled "Song of Myself."

My respiration and inspiration
. . . . the beating of my heart . . . .
the passing of blood and air
through my lungs.

div2.head: Addresses on Literature
div2.ab: Though it have all the learning and art of the schools if it has not life it is nothing If When you read or hear if it does not call the blood leaping and flowing—of —We do not fall in love with statues—we have healthy love for them
American Opera.—put three banjos, (or more?) in the orchestra—and let them accompany (at times exclusively,) the songs of the baritone or tenor—
Let a considerable part of the performance be instrumental—by the orchestra only.—
Let a few words go a great ways—the woplot not complicated but simple—Always one leading idea—as Friendship, Courage, Gratitude, Love,—always a distinct meaning—
The story and libretto as now are generally of no account.—
In the American Opera the story and libretto must be the body of the performance.
The fingers of the pianist playing lightly and rapidly over the keys.

div2.head: illustration
div2.ab: a man placing his ear
To place the ear flat on the breast of the motionless body to see if it has any life in it's heart.

div2.head: Poem
div2.ab: The land where——
The land where
The poor despised—Irish girls and boys immigrants just over

work.p: The claim here to be "the poet of the shallow and flat and despised" is probably related to a passage in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in which the narrator channels "many long dumb voices," including those of "the trivial and flat and foolish and despised."

div2.ab: A fierce protective sweep around shielding them
I am the poet of the shallow and flat and despised
Any one can may know that the great heroes and poets are divine
But

work.p: Whitman incorporated this line into the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. The poem was later titled "Song of Myself."

div2.l: The woodman that takes his axe and jug with him shall take me with him all day,

work.p: This note is possibly connected to the 1856 "Broad-Axe Poem," in which the poet asks, "What do you think endures?" The poem was later titled "Song of the Broad-Axe."

div2.ab: Poem What endures

work.p: These lines are probably related to the following line from the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass: "I have no mockings and arguments . . . . I witness and wait." The poem was eventually titled "Song of Myself."

lg.l: I have no mockings ? and laughter?
I have only to be silent ? and

work.p: This note probably represents the genesis of two passages in the fifth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in which the auctions of first a male and then a female slave are described. The poem was later titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

div2.ab: man and woman at auction

lg.l: Here is
I see—Adam and Eve again
I see the old myths
—the

div2.head: poem picture of war
—(the hospital at Sebastopol,)
div2.ab: then the opposite—the inferences and results—what war does to developedevelop and strengthen and make more energetic and agile humanity—and what it contributes to poetry, oratory, &c.—

he does not lose by comparison with the orange tree or magnolia or with the fields that nourish the sugarplant or the cottonplant . . . . all that what strengthens or clothes adorns or is luscious can be had throughsubtle counterparts from him—from him the magnolias and oranges and sugarplant and cottonplant and all fruits and flowers and all the sorts and productions of the earth.—
Poem—addressed to a young man who has come of age and is in possession of immense wealth.—

div2.head: address on literature
div2.ab: —you must become a force in the state—and a real and great force—just as real and great as the president and congress—greater than they

work.p: These lines were used in the first poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass. The poem was eventually titled "Song of Myself."

div2.ab: On South Fifth st (Monroe place) 2 doors above the river from Sixth street—going toward Greenpoint—
On Wilson st
Green, corner Fifth & Grand

work.p: It is possible that this note is related to the Preface of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, where Whitman also used the word "blatherers."

div2.ab: The wealthiesty affluent man is he who answers all the confronts wealth whatever the grandestshow sees by its an equivalent or more than equivalent in from the depths bottomless grander riches wealth of himself.—

work.p: Whitman incorporated this material into the Preface of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass.

een soo se áwnz
or the mettlesome action of the blood horse
and the unimpeachableness of the sentiment of trees
haughty & jealous and haughty instinct
